commentBody: It just clicked for me today - easy, breezy, beautiful! Well thought out puns too!
Really loved today‚Äôs‚Äîfun solve and my fastest Friday ever!
Wow, that was hard! I had to really work to get the upper left area, and I'm still figuring out why a few other things were what they were.

Great Friday puzzle!!  What a treat to be so spoiled with such a thoughtful puzzle that worked the brain folds hard!

Thanks Goldstein and Musa!
This pair, together and individually, are among the premier puzzlers of this generation.

I found this one to be a solid puzzle, with plenty of fresh answers, little glue and few proper names.

As a former lawyer (although not a TAXLAWYER), I did bristle a bit at the clue: one skilled at withholding details.  Then it dawned on me: withholding as in tax withholding, not as in hiding or refusing to produce.  With such well established constructors, I should have known better. Bravo.

So the emu filter is going to spit the first version of this out some time tomorrow.  Trying expurgation:

This was good, especially for a themeless. It felt right for a Friday even though it was very much on the easier side of things. Minimal hackneyed fill (just ewes, ants, arena).

I thought for sure it was going to be "deadlines" for a bit. I still don't like seeing "a______" in the puzzle, but the r_____l ship has sailed. These kids today.

The intersecting life-coaching spanners was a nice touch.

Solid.

This is the first time this has happened to me, maybe ever.

I only got the 34D/40A intersection by running the alphabet.

And I still don't understand either one of them!

Need a hand, here, someone.

Excellent Friday puzzle. 

Very good clueing overall, and the clues for WORKLIFEBALANCE and ELDERCARE were great, especially the latter.

Slightly too easy for what a Friday puzzle should be, but very solid.

8/10
Such a good puzzle today. Great cluing, great entries, and though I'm usually not a fan of the "?" clues, these felt just right.
Nice, clean fill and some great cluing. Had a very Robyn Weintraub feel to it - and there can be no better compliment than that.

Definitely felt like I was on Rebecca and Rafa‚Äôs wavelength. What a pleasure this was to solve. The entire west side filled in with two errors - DEAD LINeS before DEAD LINKS and ibeAm before REBAR. TIL why my son wore green and black regalia when he graduated from medical school. I had no idea ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I thought maybe it was his school colors?!  Looking forward to seeing what you have NEXT UP  in the queue for us!!

Ok, this may be the most absurd presentation glitch I've seen yet. I can see my post at https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/4au2o8?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share But when I just bring up the comments page, it isn't there. I suspect this will "correct" itself eventually, but there are some real programming problems going on here.

Sigh I‚Äôm tired of long posts that get eaten by emus, I need to start copying my posts just in case. Second try:
Got the upper left very quickly and thought I would breeze through, but the rest proved to be an enjoyable mix of clever clues, misdirects, interesting trivia (SYRIA) and a few gimmes to give me footholds‚Äîoverall about average difficulty for me. Favorite clue TAXLAWYER with ELDERCARE a close second. Had WOOD before tree and ODDS before SETS (should have known 6-0 can‚Äôt be ODDS) and ODDly enough it showed up elsewhere. Also FROST before ELIOT (head slap, should have remembered that). I thank Star Trek not only for Kirk‚Äôs birthplace but also the Shakespeare quote (The Animated Series, season two I was 12 in 1974 but still remember it!) Finally I thought CROSSWORDCOMMENTATORS was a gimme in the CRYBABIES  but it didn‚Äôt quite fit (just kidding folks, all in good fun).
Thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle.
Tough. But fun. Needed a little help. A little slower than usual. Still enjoyed a ton! Happy Friday, y‚Äôall! Thanks, Rebecca & Rafael!

I struggled at first with 6A ... because I read it as things commonly consumed by "consumers", which didn't narrow things down much. Once I saw it was "commuters" instead, the clue worked much better. Funny how that happens...
Good stuff.

I thought the clue for 6A was a hint that the answer would start with a c.  Once again I was wrong. 
I was about 2 minutes faster than my average Friday time, so, for my brain, it was a bit easy but not remarkably so.

Tickled for the Taylor clue and a deep cut as well! Currently in my eras tour pjs waiting for midnight! 

And finished the puzzle in just over 13 minutes. If you know, you know. 

ü´∂ü´∂ü´∂

One of my favorite nightmare poems... 

The Hollow Men

                              I

We are the hollow men 
We are the stuffed men 
Leaning together
Headpiece filled with straw. Alas!
Our dried voices, when 
We whisper together 
Are quiet and meaningless
As wind in dry grass 
Or rats‚Äô feet over broken glass
In our dry cellar

Shape without form, shade without colour. 
Paralysed force, gesture without motion;

Those who have crossed
With direct eyes, to death‚Äôs other Kingdom
Remember us‚Äîif at all‚Äînot as lost 
Violent souls, but only 
As the hollow men 

                              II

Eyes I dare not meet in dreams 
In death‚Äôs dream kingdom 
These do not appear:
There, the eyes are 
Sunlight on a broken column 
There, is a tree swinging
And voices are 
In the wind‚Äôs singing 
More distant and more solemn 
Than a fading star.

Let me be no nearer 
In death‚Äôs dream kingdom 
Let me also wear
Such deliberate disguises
Rat‚Äôs coat, crowskin, crossed staves
In a field
Behaving as the wind behaves 
No nearer‚Äî

Not that final meeting 
In the twilight kingdom

                              III

This is the dead land
This is cactus land
Here the stone images
Are raised, here they receive
The supplication of a dead man‚Äôs hand
Under the twinkle of a fading star.

Is it like this
In death‚Äôs other kingdom
Waking alone
At the hour when we are 
Trembling with tenderness 
Lips that would kiss
Form prayers to broken stone.

A perfect Friday puzzle, for me. I had very little on my first pass, but I persisted and filled the grid without outside help in typical Friday time. I found the Eastern half of the puzzle slightly easier than the Western one. The many unknowns were largely revealed by crosses, and with some surprisingly intelligent guesses from me. For some reason I really enjoyed the clue for KNEES. Maybe because I never before thought of a lap having ends? ü§£ I can't stand PODCASTS. When I was a teenager, my mother realized her dream of moving to a detached house. However, it was at the other end of the city than the apartment we had lived at before. The commute to school from the new place was pretty bad, so mom made it up to me by taking a huge detour on her way to work and driving me there. The thing was, she listened to talk radio. For 3 years every morning for 45 minutes I would listen to those disembodied voices droning on, torturously discussing topics I cared nothing about. I haven't been able to stand listening to talk radio or anything like it since then. When I commute these days, I stream music and do NYT puzzles or read an ebook. I find it borderline offensive when Spotify tries to push podcasts on me ü§£ Poodle time! Here's Lucek the freshly trimmed puppy playing with some of his friends at our housing estate - there's Tina the golden retriever and Pedro the mixed breed: https://imgur.com/a/pBcNOEA

I loved this puzzle.  Every clue was straightforward, but only after the fact, a masterful touch. 

I jumped all over the grid, looking for help with the crosses, which was the only way I could safely get it going.  And it didn't help when I misread a clue.  Anyone else notice that "open house" fit "realty show" just fine?  

Thank you, Rebecca and Rafael, you construct fine puzzles.  I'm looking forward to the next one.

Great puzzle with brilliant cluing.

- Miss Piggy & Captain Kirk by birth
- professional juggling act
- forget to proorfeed

Well done!
Fun fact. I did the Mini right after I booked my ACELA for tomorrow to Philly
GET ANGRY has same letter count as GO POSTAL
At first I thought it was really hard, but eventually it all poured out very easily. I liked it! If Lucas is reading this, tell him I say ‚ÄúHello!‚Äù.

Took a little while to find my start, but then I was really cranking it out ... Until the entire puzzle was solved except for the northwest corner.   I spent a while there until SKIP entered my mind to replace MUTE, and then that corner finally tucked like dominoes.

"I just listened to a show where a bunch of peas were sharing their thoughts."
"Sounds like a great pod-cast."

(It was titled "Legume with a View.")

You know how in some puzzles you can't seem to find a starting point, and you struggle and you get one here and one there and then a big one and suddenly everything falls into place?

This was exactly the opposite.  I struggled, then I'd finally find something that gave me five or six new, firm letters, but I couldn't do anything with any of them.  

Then again.  And again.  Never really getting the dominoes to fall, quite.

It finally resolved down to the PUMA/FAM cross.  So even the very last square was a struggle.

So it was a grind puzzle, but that's just fine.  I like that kind of experience, too.  Like getting a ham and cheese when you've gotten several turkey subs in a row.

a little easy for a Friday
but still a fun solve, alot of interesting and fun clues
"ANOTHER ONE" *DJ Khaled voice*
Loved it! Especially as there was no mad trivia that is impossible to guess. An incredibly well-thought out puzzle. Thanks!

‚ÄúANOTHER ONE.‚Äù

Made me imagine situations when that comment might be made.

Rebus puzzle on a Thursday.
Woodchuck in the veg garden.
Delayed train.
Power outage.

Uhoh, then I got dark thinking about current events at home

[This]
[That]

Palate cleanser needed!

Fruit scone.
Lap snuggles with cat.
Punster Mike‚Äôs daily.

Nothing 21 Acrossed about this beauty by Rebecca and Rafael. Thanks, guys.
Liked the new take on a clue for EWES.

‚ÄòBoxing Day mo.‚Äô on a Friday??? Really?? 
I think you meant to put this crossword on a Wednesday‚Ä¶

It seemed easy for a Friday, didn‚Äôt it? 
Liked it though.

This was a treat, the kind of grid that doesn't have many grips at first but each fill helps find another. It wasn't the hardest ever as others are saying, but beautifully constructed - I made much more use of crosses than I do on an actual easy puzzle.
Enjoyed this, but the national symbol of England is a rose.

Maybe I'm being overly sensitive, but SCAB as it's defined here is a pretty offensive derogatory term in the UK (a label that has led to people being ostracized from their communities, and violence committed against them and their families) - I've seen it used multiple times with the strikebreaker definition in the NYT crossword.

Would be nice to see its other definition used more often - e.g. "Protective covering", "Encrust", "Don't pick it!". Or are people just too squeamish for that üòè ?
Lovely puzzle. Flowed really nicely. Well under my average time but a fun solve!

Rebecca Goldstein and Rafael Musa are two of my favorite constructors.  I smiled as soon as I saw their names.

They went a little easy on us today but still employed their usual clever cluing.  I found this to be a little more challenging than recent Friday puzzles, but not as tough as I expect from the two of them.

Favorites were [Service to foster parents?] for ELDER CARE and [Ones skilled at withholding details] for TAX LAWYER.

‚ÄúForgets to proorfeed, say‚Äù‚Ä¶ ü§£. The funniest thing about this was how long it took for me to see the ERRor. I would be a terrible proorfeeder!

‚ÄúOne end of a lap‚Äù: I entered KNEES as a joke. It‚Äôs always nice to have the same weird sense of humor as the constructor.
Tour de force in Friday construction if you ask me. It was everything I love in a themeless puzzle and more.

Very, very nice. I agree with all the good things others have said.

Lots of good guesses, but the tricky ones for me - 'on deck' - assumed a ship connection; and I spell it 'vices', not 'vises'.

Smashing.
A really enjoyable puzzle for me. Good entries cleverly clued. Thanks, Rebecca and Rafa!
Good one! I liked ‚ÄúWhat comes before we go?‚Äù, and found that ‚Äúupnext‚Äù could also be NEXTUP.

Spot. On.

I ate it up.

Ask anyone.
Who else confidently slapped in MUTE for [Not listen to, as on Spotify]?
Raced through this one in half the time of Thursday‚Äôs stumper! But still an interesting themeless. Just a  tough Thursday, easy Friday.
This one was really rewarding. I tend to get impatient after the 20 minute mark and start making excuses and cheat, but today I stuck it out and am glad that I did. Thanks!

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	One way to make the solver grateful for a dull answer is with a clue that zings, and that‚Äôs just what Rebecca/Rafael made with [One skilled at withholding details] for TAX LAWYER.
‚Ä¢	AROSE sweetly evoked Gertrude Stein.
‚Ä¢	It is so hard to construct triple-stacks without creating clunky crosses ‚Äì even harder when there are two crossing spanners, and today those four stacks are silky smooth.  Mwah!
‚Ä¢	LILY evoked an old song ‚ÄúHi-Lili, Hi-Lo‚Äù, a calming influence through my childhood.
‚Ä¢	PLEASE BE PATIENT ‚Äì such good advice.  Several times today I abandoned a thorny spot only to return in a bit to find it obvious.
‚Ä¢	Verve in the cluing ‚Äì humor and wordplay ‚Äì in a luscious compendium of original and encore clues.
‚Ä¢	Beauty along the way ‚Äì ASK ANYONE, WORK-LIFE BALANCE, PLEASE BE PATIENT, EATS IT UP, CRYBABIES.
‚Ä¢	When I saw ANTS touching PEDANT, my brain shouted ‚ÄúRed ant!‚Äù.

Lively, lovely, and satisfying.  You hit the trifecta today, Rebecca and Rafael.  Thank you for this!
Fun, bright and breezy.

Quite enjoyable Friday puzzle. Was it quick for me? Nope - not even 'half fast' (cough), but just had good time working through it. And nice to see a self-reference at 18a (I still get a chunk of change every month for that). And... ended up with one wrong square. Didn't catch it after a quick review, so just went ahead and did a check. End of streak, no big deal. 

Couple of fun puzzle finds today. I'll put those in replies. 

...
Very nice puzzle. I knew when I saw the names of the constructors that it would be a good one. Thanks, Rebecca and Rafael!
I read "The Hollow Men" and "The Second Coming" at the same time at school, so I got them confused this morning. Caused me problems since Yeats fits just fine in the space haha

I was finished in under 10 minutes...... Until I got stuck at the crossing of "fished off the coast of Maine" and "vast amount" I got there in the end by running through the alphabet and now feel supply that I didn't see it!!!
Perfect Friday puzzle with nice lively entries, minimal gunk and some great wordplay. End of a lap and withholding details were particularly good

One of my bugaboos is misreading the clue. Today's: reading "under a mare's care" (easy enough answer) as "under a man's care." A WARD, right? Those are the hardest for me to catch, because once you misread the clue, your brain keeps seeing it that way.
Really good, solid puzzle.
Thoroughly enjoyed this one. For once, (on a Friday) I was on the same wavelength as the creators. No baseball references, no nostalgic brand names, no crosswordese. Nicely done. Thank you.
My god, one more Taylor Swift reference in the crossword and I‚Äôll cancel my subscription.
I really really liked this one.
Please allow me to pile on the praise.  Perfection.

I liked it, too. But, it was too easy for a Friday. I know I should be careful for what I wish, but, please make this late-week puzzles a bit more challenging. 

tc
I really liked this. And as for it being an easy Friday puzzle? After last week I thought it was a welcome change!

Wow I‚Äôve never seen a puzzle so universally praised. With the minor nit of the FAM/PUMA cross (which is clueing, not fill) I haven‚Äôt seen any negative reviews. I don‚Äôt keep a POY list but for those who do this ought to be on it.
Re 12D, just a quibble but there is something called a strawberry tree. They‚Äôre quite pretty and the fruit is edible.
PLEASE BE PATIENT? No! I want more collaborations between Rebecca Goldstein and Rafael Musa, and I want them now!

[Slapdash marketing slogan for a new doctor's office]





PLEASE BE PATIENT
I never comment but this puzzle was so perfect I had to say something. More like this please! And great work!

I mentioned in my response to Francis that the temperature reached -55¬∞ when we lived in Wisconsin. It was February 2019. That included wind chill factor. It was a polar vortex. This link explains more: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/January%E2%80%93February_2019_North_American_cold_wave?wprov=sfti1 It wasn‚Äôt a typo or exaggeration on my part. I screenshot the weather channel app as well as news station alerts. Most miserable week of my life.

'Cause you know I love the players,
And you love the game.

...was the first thing I heard this morning when my clock radio kicked on* and I knew I was in for a rough day. I turned on Fox Biz, and sure enough, they're talking about how the Swifties will be flooding movie theaters this weekend for the album release. Then I opened up the puzzle. Ugh, make it stop! I just hope Tay-Tay and Travis have a good TAX LAWYER or ten. Ye gods, the woman's worth $1.6 billion! Other than that and FAM, a fine Friday puzzle.

*My ancient clock radio is tuned to a station I don't particularly care for, but one that has a reliably strong signal. It also encourages me to be up and about.

- I had deadlines instead of deadlinks and foal instead of colt. Those are misdirects, I take it? Good ones, at that!
- Someone please explain a Vans alternative? Sneakers? Fast feline?
- Quick rebar story. I had three 12-foot pieces of rebar and needed to cut them into 4-foot lengths. After snapping four blades on my trusty DeWalt reciprocating saw and jarring my fillings loose, a hand held hack saw worked best. Of course, my forearms looked like Popeye‚Äôs afterwards, but the job was done. AND it was 93 degrees outside. ONLY an acetylene torch cuts rebar, trust me.  I think I'd rather fend off panicking alpaca in a holding pen than to try that again.
- The British bum had me drumming up all sorts of words like sot, tramp, and the such. However, It seems only fit that HALFARSE would be the solution to an olde English word like ‚Äòslapdash.‚Äô But I failed at (Yukon) JACK instead of LION for England‚Äôs national symbol, so what do I know.

This one just flowed from my pen (er, finger) with hardly a single snag.  Liked it very much. I realize that ‚Äúyour mileage may vary‚Äù but ‚Ä¶ and there are plenty of puzzles that have really puzzled me (see what I did there?) but this was a winner for me!  Service to foster parents was a great misdirect!
Found this Friday puzzle surprisingly easy! Yay!

Constructors: What does amuse-bouche mean.
NY Times: Why the heck are cuss words getting in these puzzles? Really now, ARSE and HALFASSED? Don't get me wrong. I cuss like the proverbial truckdriver, but i expect more class in the paper of record--even in its games.

Feel free to call me a PEDANT.....but if you're too darned lazy to add the -ED to a term meaning "Slapdash," then you really need to assess your LIFE choices.  Maybe you're just not a Word Person.  

40A gave me the most trouble...Vans or SUVS drove me crazy for a couple of minutes.  The M was my last entry.  (There are just too many brands of footwear these days, eh?)

RATS before ANTS
COLT before FOAL
Self-CARE?  Who DOES?
And haven't our British solvers pointed out the crass nature of 46D as an entry in a NYT publication?  ASK ANYONE.

My work here is done.

i keep looking at 2D and it still feels awful wobbly.
this was the only use i found today for my lice comb.  putting it away now.
otherwise perfectly fine friday.
ive apparently gotten jaded after 9 months and gone full-metal esthete about my crosswords:  if they dont proustian madeleine (should be a verb) me or cause me to stare in awe at the finished grid all slack-jawed and stupid and warm i just go about my day and wait for tomorrows puzzle.

I got 21A from the crosses, but was irritated at HAL-FASS. Then the penny dropped. It‚Äôs fascinating how difficult it can be to decipher undivided consecutive words. Many early Latin manuscripts were written in this fashion. Sheesh, on top of learning Latin you have to figure out the darned words!  
EPL-URIB-USUN-UM.  Um‚Ä¶indeed.

The very upper left was smooth sailing for me and I thought I would breeze through this, but instead I found the rest a nice mix of some misdirects, interesting trivia (SYRIA) and clever clues along with some gimmes that helped me get footholds‚ÄîI‚Äôd say average Friday difficulty for me overall.  Favorite clue TAXLAWYER with ELDERCARE a  close second. Had WOOD before TREE and ODDS before SETS (stupid 6-0 can‚Äôt be ODDS and ODDly enough it ended up being another entry) and FROST before ELIOT (head slap). Thank you Star Trek not only for Kirk‚Äôs birthplace but also the Shakespeare quote (The animated series Season Two, I was 12 in 1974 but still remember it!!!)
Finally couldn‚Äôt quite fit CROSSWORDCOMMENTATORS in the CRYBABIES spot I thought for sure that was a gimme! ( Just kidding folks all in good fun).
I enjoyed this puzzle, but I'm really just here to watch y'all complain about Taylor.
Wow, I did my first Friday puzzle! I‚Äôm working my way through the week. I‚Äôm eventually coming for you Sunday!

30D. Haven't thought of this expression in years, but the great comedian Jack Benny used to end his TV monologs with "AWAY WE GO",  and then he would do this little vaudevillian shuffle stage left.  No one could do a "slow burn" like Jack Benny. Just saying his name makes name laugh.

I have a renewed respect for how hard it is to create good, solid grids like this after making a puzzle of my own last month.

I quite liked the misdirect on 56 across: something raised in Octoberfest could have you thinking IPA STEIN... which I'm sure we're all glad it wasn't.
With "easy mode" clues handy, Friday puzzles are easier than Manadays'

I like a puzzle that's (a little) harder than expected, so, for me, this was an excellent puzzle.

Great clues.  
Favorites:
"Professional juggling act?"
"One skilled at withholding details"
"Service to foster parents?"
"Something raised during Oktoberfest"

Great answers. Favorites:
CRYBABIES
ASK ANYONE
PLEASE BE PATIENT

And almost no common fill:
No Oreos or Onos, 
and ERAS and EELED were well-clued, so they get a pass.

And a nice bit of TIL with the "oldest discovered library."

All in all, an excellent puzzle.
Not surprising from the team of Goldstein and Musa.
Thanks!

WORKLIFEBALANCE was, for me, the answer of the year. 

From watching my parents, then working alongside my wife while raising three children, to now living with a son who is working two jobs to raise his children, it captures the challenges that affect almost every decision of our day to day lives.

A fun Friday puzzle!  Today I had to solve this solo (my partner is visiting her family this weekend). Started with 1A as usual and thought of SANDS but was thinking (like @Lewis) that 1D was mute. So I took it out and went to another part of the puzzle. The NE was my breakthrough, then the SW, SE.  Finally returned to the NW and SANDS was right.  Excellent clueing, nice long answers, very little junky fill.  Liked PLEASE BE PATIENT and WORK/LIFE BALANCE. Finished a little under our average.
I thought KNEES was clever wordplay - as in one end of the word "lap", which would be a KNEESlap. Anyone else?

Excellent, quality clueing and fill today! Even the few common cw entries had fresh clues. HALFASS was my DOOK today ("what's a HAL FASS?" üòÇ), and rats before ANTS with here before AWAY, cOlt before FOAL, slowed down that left side. I've visited the MONTE CARLO. Absolutely gorgeous building (and I even came away with a couple hundred extra euros üòâ)
Fabulous Friday. Happy birthday, Rafael!
Distraction and misdirection on this gem was epic. Thanks! Great job, kept me on my toes!

Late to the game.  Wanna post. Before I read. 

i have a bad memory. But late week puzzles of the year (fri/sat) for me. 

The only two? Proper nouns?
The long entry phrases?  Amazing. Almost too many good ones for one puzzle. 
WORKLIFE.BALANCE crossing PLEASE.BE.PATIENT


plus 
ASK.ANYONE
RED.CARPET
CRYBABIES
ANOTHER.ONE (shoutout BEER.TENT)
DOCUSERIES 
MONTE.CARLO

NEWS.ALERT
this is the greatest long entry gold I can ever remember. This is my new standard.
So funnnnn. Great long answers. The misdirects. Yum yum. Thank you!
50:57, 3:59 faster than average. Nice clean fill. Gave up secrets a little at a time. Bottom right was the last to fall.

Discovered that "keep your shirt on" has the same number of letters as PLEASE BE PATIENT.

I tend to react better to the second one.

Any crossword that incorporates TS ELIOT, King LEAR and Miss Piggy gets my vote. A cracking Friday puzzle; fast but fun. Love the HALFASS/ARSE combo.
Can‚Äôt understand the grumbling re Ms Swift. I‚Äôm no fan, I couldn‚Äôt name a single song, but the woman has carved out an astounding career and is clearly adored by millions, so she‚Äôs doing something right. Is it a generational thing? I refuse to believe it‚Äôs anything nefarious from the upstanding NYT crowd.
I now have ‚Äòthe man who broke the bank at MONTE CARLO‚Äô stuck in my head.

Didn't solve and didn't enjoy, though the former didn't directly cause the latter.

No idea about Vans or PUMA, so guessed that "Besties, maybe" was "FAS", which might have been some insipid shortening for "Friends always". No longer cared what PUSA might be.

Wednesday grid, presumably with clues reworked to run on Friday. Quite the let down (for me) from yesterday's gem.
the crossword truly teaches PATIENCE. as a new solver, getting a friday with no tips is reason to celebrate. made the connection between monte carlo simulations and the actual city today, thanks NYT!
Great puzzle, i was a little sad that i had to rework ‚ÄúTAXEVADER‚Äù bc i thought that was a pretty clever response.

Apparently ‚Äúpedants‚Äù were originally a group of people paid by the intelligentsia to travel around and hit people with sticks when they made grammatical or etymological errors - thus, ‚Äústicklers‚Äù.

Any care to challenge me on this‚Ä¶ peacefully?

A good puzzle. (Also open to debate on this subject.)
Is there a term of art for when you think a puzzle is harder than usual for the day of the week, but you somehow finish under your average time? Whatever that's called, that's me today.

One more late puzzle find. A Monday from October 13, 1997 by Gregory E. Paul. Three theme answers in that one. HOLDYOURHORSES MINDYOURMANNERS BITEYOURTONGUE And... MINDYOURMANNERS was the only one of those that ever appeared in another Shortz era puzzle. And BITEYOURTONGUE never appeared in any other puzzle. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/13/1997&g=38&d=A ....

First Friday puzzle I've finished without having to go back and find my mistakes or use any hints. Experienced a new type of joy when the jingle happened instead of the puzzle telling me something was wrong.
Who knew Miss Piggy was from Iowa?!
We've entered a new era of TOOT and I'm here for it.

I have two problems with the crossword someone might be able to help with.  First, I can't get it to any sort of full screen view; I have to waste time scrolling up to see the across clues when I get about halfway down the puzzle.  Secondly, I'm a bit obsessed with time, and can't stop the times while I adjust the settings.  I doubt there is a solution to that. :(
Well, this wasn't good. Witty and inventive is not the same as misleading or imprecise. And filling most of it with phrases instead of words is cheap and random.
This puzzle was just frustrating to me. Not fun at all.

Omg
A proper mental workout.

I sailed through the first part but then got stuck in the NW and SE corners. I had to stop and come back to this multiple times, each time chipping away a bit more but I refused to give in and look anything up.

I really got stuck at thinking that emu was the animal (contains mu) and when I finally got rid of that to EWE, that part of the puzzle opened up. A worthy Friday or even Saturday challenge. Tough but fair.

Really fun and challenging too. NW corner was my last trouble spot. Did not have any idea where Miss Piggy and Captain Kirk could both be from, and also sadly not up on Taylor Swift. 
But I really enjoyed the puzzle. Thanks Rebecca and Rafael.

This puzzle reminds me of the time I worked as a clown for Ringling Brothers and the stunt I performed each night involved jumping spread eagle over a four foot tall open flame and my nickname at the time was Smooth Sack Rogers.
This puzzle was a total bust for me. I maybe got around 20% filled in. I wish I could've had as much fun as those of you who loved it. Oh well, more puzzles to come.

Thought this was a bust and a streak ender when I got through my first pass! @Francis

It's beautiful and terrifying to me. I used to have it pinned to my bulletin board. I guess I like to freak myself out. üòú

@Gareth
I used to borrow the "between the X and the Y falls the Shadow" lines and Hamlet's "the native hue of resolution is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought" speech  when teaching about intentionality in religious thought. Great poem, indeed!

@Francis
All readers of poetry are "competent." As you implied, poems reveal more meaning as you reread them. An explanation of a poem might add something you hadn't noticed or explain something you hadn't understood, but the explicator is only giving a version of what they saw in the poem.  It's a way of talking about poems, but it isn't poetry.   

Memorize a poem you like, and you will be more likely to understand its meaning more fully than anything anyone can tell you about it.

Poetry is always meant to communicate more than the words by themselves, and when you embrace a poem, it can express feelings and perceptions and understanding that will enrich your soul.

@Mattü¶óü¶óü¶ó

@SBK
In HTML (and some other web stuff) a less than sign indicates that everything up to and including the matching greater than sign is either in instruction about how to display the following text (e.g., embolden it), something turning that instruction off, or something content-related (like the address of a link).  So the emus aren't even seeing what you typed in.  There are ways to make these symbols appear...

For my fellow Yanks, the Jules Rimet Trophy was the original World Cup. It was stolen in 1983, and never recovered.

@Tim

I fear its casual usage may be yet another sign that unions as we know them are both irrelevant and disappearing.

My carpenter father was a union man, and I think he would have thought of the term as very derogatory.

And I think it's no coincidence that the destruction of the unions and the beginning of low wages never gaining on inflation emerged in the mid 70s together.  So I mourn the loss of the unions--I was never really in one except on a provisional basis for college jobs.

So I agree with you, other than it seems to be the fading lingo of a mostly resolved war.

Also, my father was a union truck driver, and the truckers‚Äô strikes of the early 70s in America are steeped in violence. It's unfortunate that much of the freedoms we enjoy today have endured a history of protests and violent clashes, and those are somehow remembered the most. I can cite the struggle for America‚Äôs independence, yet almost the entirety of our New England cities retain their original names.

America‚Äôs ‚Äúcancel culture,‚Äù (statues, flags, renaming, book banning) of eliminating/rewriting history‚Ä¶ has that been effective? Reminders, even ones that invoke darkness, are all around us.

I'm pretty sure that "All hands on deck!" doesn't mean that they're NEXT UP.

Steve,

Actually, it does.

@Barry Ancona
An English idiom with more than one meaning. How unusual.

@Barry Ancona The concept of "on deck" was borrowed from naval terminology, but the specific concept of as "next in line" was not. In naval terminology, "on deck" meant "at hand, ready for action." This Wikipedia article https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_English-language_idioms_derived_from_baseball#O states that OED mentions usage of "on deck" first in 1867 in the context of baseball ("on deck fig. [orig. U.S.]: at hand; ready for action; alive; in Baseball, next at the bat, with the right or privilege of batting next". The naval sense has nothing to do with taking one's turn.

If I remember correctly, you are originally from Iowa. My husband spends a lot of time there with his business. Mostly Des Moines, Cedar Rapids, and Ames.

HeathieJ,

My younger daughter taught school for one semester in Brooklyn, Iowa. Her students enjoyed that she had gone to school in Brooklyn, New York.

When I worked on the Rock Island, and people asked me where I was from, I told them I was born "a little west of Brooklyn." 

(Riverside, south of Iowa City, was on a long-gone Rock Island branch line. Keystone is west of Cedar Rapids and was on the late Milwaukee Road.)

Having lived in Iowa City for eleven years and bicycled to Trek Fest, I knew for sure that Captain Kirk is a future Iowan! Didn't know Miss Piggy was also from Iowa :-)
